question.title: Access protected fields of a subclass in a superclass?

node.contents: This seems backwards since a super class should have no knowledge of nor dependence on sub classes. Why would you even want to consider this? My advise would be to re-design your code so that it wouldn't need this crazy requirement.

astNode.text: This seems backwards since a super class should have no knowledge of nor dependence on sub classes. Why would you even want to consider this? My advise would be to re-design your code so that it wouldn't need this crazy requirement.

node.contents: Sure, you can do all kinds of crazy things reflection. Like put a gun to your foot and pull the trigger. You have the code written, *try it*!

astNode.text: Sure, you can do all kinds of crazy things reflection. Like put a gun to your foot and pull the trigger. You have the code written, *try it*!

node.contents: Reason is that i wanted to annotate Subclass fields so I can work with the annotated fields in the superclass. (i.e: which fields should be saved on a DB)? Bad design? Okay, I'll think about it again, thanks!

astNode.text: Reason is that i wanted to annotate Subclass fields so I can work with the annotated fields in the superclass. (i.e: which fields should be saved on a DB)? Bad design? Okay, I'll think about it again, thanks!

node.contents: Is it possible to access a protected member from Subclass in a SuperClass using reflection?

astNode.text: Is it possible to access a protected member from Subclass in a SuperClass using reflection?

elements.contents: private void accessFields() { Field[] fields = this.getClass().getDeclaredFields(); for(Field field : fields) { if(Modifier.isProtected(field.getModifiers()) { //Will this always work? Or will get(this) throw an IllegalAccessException? Object value = field.get(this); } } }

comments.text: //Will this always work? Or will get(this) throw an IllegalAccessException? Object value = field.get(this); } } }

node.contents: Note that this would be the opposite way of the common protected member access, not the SubClass accesses the protected member, but the SuperClass.

astNode.text: Note that this would be the opposite way of the common protected member access, not the SubClass accesses the protected member, but the SuperClass.

node.contents: You can do anything with reflection. You can even directly manipulate the memory of the JVM if you feel like it (sun.misc.Unsafe).

astNode.text: You can do anything with reflection. You can even directly manipulate the memory of the JVM if you feel like it (sun.misc.Unsafe).

node.contents: However, if you don't normally have access, you'll need to use setAccessible or similar.

astNode.text: However, if you don't normally have access, you'll need to use setAccessible or similar.

node.contents: Thanks, this answers my question, if it is possible or not.

astNode.text: Thanks, this answers my question, if it is possible or not.

node.contents: You can access any field of an object (private, protected, public) using reflection. It doesn't matter if the class accessing the private fields of an object is its super class or sub class (when using reflection).

astNode.text: You can access any field of an object (private, protected, public) using reflection. It doesn't matter if the class accessing the private fields of an object is its super class or sub class (when using reflection).

node.contents: As long as you can get an object of the "PrivateObject" Class, you can access its fields. Do remember to field.setAccessible(true) to access non-public fields.

astNode.text: As long as you can get an object of the "PrivateObject" Class, you can access its fields. Do remember to field.setAccessible(true) to access non-public fields.
